title: wandering_paragraphs
description: I feel like my paragraphs wander.
solution: Try outlining each paragraph’s main idea in a single sentence before writing to keep focus and structure clear.

title: perfectionist
description: I am perfecting each paragraph before moving on, and it's taking too long to write.
solution: Try constructing a general outline of what subjects you want to cover.

title: narrow_topic
description: I am having trouble narrowing down my topic.
solution: Focus on diagnosing why your topic feels overwhelming.

title: too_many_subtopics
description: I have too many subtopics in mind.
solution: Let’s figure out whether your challenge is interest or evidence, then prioritize accordingly.

next.label: I feel equally interested in all of them and can’t choose
I’m worried some subtopics won’t have enough sources or evidence

title: too_many_subtopics_interest
description: I feel equally interested in all of them and can’t choose.
solution: Rank each subtopic by how excited you feel about it right now. Choose the top 1 or 2 to start writing on, and remind yourself you can explore others later.

title: too_many_subtopics_evidence
description: I’m worried some subtopics won’t have enough sources or evidence.
solution: Do a quick 10-minute search for key sources on each subtopic. Prioritize the ones with the strongest, most accessible evidence.

title: vague_topic
solution: Clarify your argument and language to transform a vague topic into a strong, specific thesis.

next.label: I’m stating what the topic is, not what I think about it
My language is full of general or abstract words

title: vague_topic_argument
description: I’m stating what the topic is, not what I think about it.
solution: Turn your topic into an argument by finishing this sentence: 'I will argue that ___ because ___.' This helps you move from description to analysis.

title: vague_topic_language
description: My language is full of general or abstract words.
solution: Replace vague words with specific nouns and active verbs. For example, swap 'effects' with 'decline in readership' or 'themes' with 'depictions of isolation.'

title: cant_decide_angle
description: I can’t decide which angle to take.
solution: Write down three possible angles in one sentence each. Choose the one that feels most exciting to you—not the one that seems 'safest'. Your engagement will make the writing stronger.

title: adding_more_ideas
description: I keep adding more ideas as I go.
solution: Treat your first choice as a case study—one slice of the bigger idea. You can always note the wider context briefly in your intro or conclusion.

title: topic_too_small
description: I’m worried my topic will be too small
solution: Let’s explore whether you need to deepen your topic or connect it to bigger themes.

next.label: I’m trying to make my topic bigger by adding unrelated ideas
I don’t see the significance of my specific topic

title: topic_too_small_widening
description: I’m trying to make my topic bigger by adding unrelated ideas.
solution: Instead of widening the topic, deepen it. Ask 'Why does this matter?' multiple times to explore layers of meaning within your narrow focus.

title: topic_too_small_significance
description: I don’t see the significance of my specific topic.
solution: Connect your topic to a bigger conversation or theme. Show how your narrow focus reveals something important about the broader subject.

title: writers_block
description: I have writer's block and don't know how to get started
solution: Identify whether the block is at the sentence level or structure level, and pick a path to break the impasse.

next.label: I don’t know how to start the first sentence
I feel overwhelmed by structure and organization

title: writers_block_start
description: I don’t know how to start the first sentence.
solution: Skip the introduction entirely and write an easy body paragraph first. Getting words down reduces pressure and builds momentum.

title: writers_block_structure
description: I feel overwhelmed by structure and organization.
solution: Write a simple bullet list of 3–5 points you want to cover. Use that as a roadmap to guide your writing step-by-step.
